Incorporating strength training into your existing routine can be challenging, but with a little creativity, you can make it work. Here are some suggestions to help you fit strength training into your schedule:

**Replace one spinning class with strength training**: If you're currently taking three spinning classes per week, consider replacing one of them with a strength training session. This will allow you to maintain your cardiovascular fitness while adding strength training to your routine.

**Add strength training to your rest days**: If you have rest days or easy workout days, consider adding strength training to those days. This will help you maintain your cardiovascular fitness while allowing you to recover from intense spinning classes.

**Split your strength training into shorter sessions**: If you can't fit a full strength training session into your schedule, consider splitting it into shorter sessions. For example, you could do 20-30 minutes of strength training on two or three days per week, focusing on different muscle groups each day.

**Schedule strength training around your spinning classes**: If you have a spinning class in the morning, consider doing strength training in the evening or vice versa. This will help you fit both activities into your schedule without conflicting with each other.

**Make it a habit**: Consistency is key when it comes to strength training. Try to schedule strength training at the same time every week, so it becomes a habit. You can also try to find a workout buddy or accountability partner to help motivate you.

Here's an example of how you could incorporate strength training into your existing routine:

Monday: Spinning class (morning) + strength training (evening, 20-30 minutes)
Tuesday: Rest day
Wednesday: Spinning class (morning)
Thursday: Rest day + strength training (evening, 20-30 minutes)
Friday: Spinning class (morning)
Saturday: Rest day
Sunday: Long ride or brick workout (morning) + strength training (afternoon, 20-30 minutes)

Remember to listen to your body and adjust your schedule as needed. It's better to start with a manageable schedule and gradually increase the frequency and intensity of your strength training sessions.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
